text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
) Updated general citation format in IRM
) Added new program, scope, and objective content as per IRM
) The word “Section” removed from all citation links, to permit the links to the provider to work as designed.

Certain information, including identifying details, about written determinations and background ﬁle documents must be deleted (redacted) (IRC 6110(c)).
Note: Previously, 26 CFR 301.6110-1 provided an exception for the public disclo- sure of EO denials and revocations.

Exempt Organizations Disclosure Procedures
Gives guidance on the exhaustion of administrative remedies for declara- tory judgment under IRC 7428 and guidance on applicable user fees for requesting determination letters.

Acronym/Abbreviation Deﬁnition CFR Code of Federal Regulations EO Exempt Organizations EODQA Exempt Organizations Determina- tions Quality Assurance IRC Internal Revenue Code Rev. Proc. Revenue Procedure Treas. Reg. Treasury Regulation
A “written determination” means a ruling, determination letter, technical advice memorandum, or Chief Counsel advice. A “background ﬁle document” for a written determination includes:
The request for that written determination
Any material submitted in support of the request
Any communication, written or otherwise, between the IRS and persons outside the IRS in connection with the written determination received before issuance of the written determination
Communications between the Department of Justice and the IRS for a pending civil or criminal case or investigation aren’t background ﬁle documents.
Inspection of Written Determinations Under 6110 7.28.4

on the front page of the written determination. Enter contact date and the category of the person making the contact in the heading of the letter. Example: Contact categories may include Congressional, Department Commerce, Department of Treasury, Trade Association, House, Educational Institution, etc.
The following types of determination letters issued by EO Rulings and Agree- ments are subject to IRC Section 6110:
Insert the Uniform Issue List (UIL) index number on the ﬁrst page of the letter.
Record third party communications (per 26 CFR 301.6110-4) in the case chro- nology record and on the front page of the determination letter.

Record any communication (whether written, by telephone, at a meeting, or otherwise) the IRS received before issuing a written determination from any person other than the organization to which the determination pertains or that organization’s authorized representative. Note all contacts that qualify as third-party communications under
CFR
on the front page of the written determination. Enter the contact date and the category of the person making the contact in the heading of the letter.
Note: See IRM 25.27.1, Third Party Contact Program, for procedures governing IRS initiated third-party contacts subject to IRC
Review the letter template for any citations. Continue to use any citation format throughout the rest of the letter.
7.28 Exempt Organizations Disclosure Procedures
Example: If the letter template initially references “Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 501(c)(3),” continue using the citation format “IRC Section 501(c)(3).”
Use the following general citation formats if the published letter template doesn’t have any embedded citations:

For Use The ﬁrst reference to the Internal Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Revenue Code (IRC) in the letter Section Subsequent references to the IRC Section IRC (ﬁrst reference in a paragraph) Additional references to the IRC Section [Insert] in the same paragraph with prior references The ﬁrst reference to the Treasury Regulation Section Treasury Regulations in the letter [Insert] Subsequent references to the Treas. Reg. Section [Insert] Treasury Regulations in the letter
Note: Some letter templates include these headings. Templates may also have prepared text for some headings.
tax law references of the same category in numerical or date order, even if aren’t referenced or discussed in that order in the rest of the letter.
Public Inspection of Written Determinations Under IRC 6110 7.28.4

) Before any written determination or background ﬁle document is made available for public inspection, delete (redact) certain information. IRC lists material to redact, including the following: a. The names, addresses, and other identifying details of the person to whom the written determination pertains and of any other person, than a person with respect to whom a notation is made under IRC

), identiﬁed in the written determination or any background document b. Information speciﬁcally authorized under criteria established by an Executive Order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense foreign policy, and which is in fact properly classiﬁed per such Order c. Information speciﬁcally exempted from disclosure by any statute than this title) which is applicable to the IRS d. Trade secrets and commercial or ﬁnancial information obtained from person and is privileged or conﬁdential e. Information, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly ranted invasion of personal privacy f. Information contained in, or related to, examination, operating, or condition reports prepared by, or on behalf of, or for use of an responsible for the regulation or supervision of ﬁnancial institutions g. Geological and geophysical information and data, including maps, cerning wells (
) The most common deletions under IRC Section
are the names, addresses, and other identifying details of all entities and individuals. (

) Consider deleting other identifying details from the determination letter as: • Names of local IRS officers and employees • Authorized representatives (names of individuals and possibly ﬁrm names) • Director/shareholder information • Organization/taxpayer location, including state of incorporation • Business location (city and state) • Dollar ﬁgures • Dates, including tax years • Percentages • Type of business if unique or industry is small • Countries of operation • Region, district, city, circuit court • References to state law • References to unique federal law that impacts few industries or als • Product lines • Court docket numbers • Policy numbers • Outside consultants (names of individuals and possibly ﬁrm • References to another case involving the same taxpayer(s) • Beneﬁciaries • Patents and trademarks Internal Revenue Manual

a. The names, addresses, and other identifying details of the person to whom the written determination pertains and of any other person, than a person with respect to whom a notation is made under IRC

), identiﬁed in the written determination or any background document b. Information speciﬁcally authorized under criteria established by an Executive Order to be kept secret in the interest of national defense foreign policy, and which is in fact properly classiﬁed per such Order c. Information speciﬁcally exempted from disclosure by any statute than this title) which is applicable to the IRS d. Trade secrets and commercial or ﬁnancial information obtained from person and is privileged or conﬁdential e. Information, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwar- ranted invasion of personal privacy f. Information contained in, or related to, examination, operating, or condition reports prepared by, or on behalf of, or for use of an agency responsible for the regulation or supervision of ﬁnancial institutions g. Geological and geophysical information and data, including maps, cerning wells
The most common deletions under IRC Section 6110 are the names, addresses, and other identifying details of all entities and individuals.

Exempt Organizations Disclosure • Any quotations from an opinion or searchable database (e.g., SEC ﬁlings), if they are associated with the taxpayer • Extensions of time or general time frames • Any other information that could be cross-referenced in other available sets of information including electronic databases (such as quotes from a website) Create a legend on the ﬁrst page of the letter to deﬁne substitutions of ing information. Generally: • Use capital letters to represent names of individuals, corporations, places, businesses, and most numbers. Example: B, C, D, etc. Caution: To avoid confusion, don’t use “A” or “I”. • Use lower case letters to represent percentages and, when used dollars, to represent sums of money. Example: x percent, x dollars Caution: To avoid confusion, don’t use “a”. Also, if you use a letter (per above), don’t use that same letter in lower (e.g., X and x). • Add a generic descriptor for each legend item on the redacted copy the letter. Example: B = Board Member

• Use speciﬁc dates only when it’s important to the issue analysis and ultimate conclusion or reference a general time frame as a an actual date. Example: You were incorporated during the time of desegregation.
Exempt Organizations Disclosure Procedures
Any quotations from an opinion or searchable database (e.g., SEC ﬁlings), if they are associated with the taxpayer Extensions of time or general time frames Any other information that could be cross
referenced in other publicly available sets of information including electronic databases (such as quotes from a website)
Use capital letters to represent names of individuals, places, businesses, and most numbers.
Use lower case letters to represent percentages and, when used with dollars, to represent sums of money.
Example: x percent, x dollars
Caution: To avoid confusion, don’t use “a”. Also, if you use a capital letter (per above), don’t use that same letter in lower case (e.g., X and x).
Example: You were incorporated during the time of desegregation.
Replace identifying information in the letter text with the legend item.
Example: You incorporated in the state of N.
Any other employee responsible for submitting an EO written determination for IRC Section 6110 publication follows the same general procedures.
Review the letter to ensure all identifying information is removed from the redacted copy. (See also IRM
, Review Procedures for EO Determina- tions.)
Reminder: Identifying information includes EINs, organizations’ names and addresses, identifying information in legends, and specialist names and contact numbers.

(4) Save an electronic copy of the letter and other documents using the EIN and a generic description of the letter (for example type of letter) or document.
Example: nn-nnnnnnn Proposed Adverse, nn-nnnnnnn Proposed Adverse Redacted, nn-nnnnnnn Notice 437, etc.
) Email the letters and forms to
Disclosure@irscounsel.treas.gov. Type “IRC
Package” in the subject line. (

) The public may request in writing to receive a redacted copy of the back- ground ﬁle documents for written determinations which have been released public inspection. The Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch, Legal Pro- cessing Division, Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration) is responsible for processing this type of written request. (

) The Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch contacts the EO Rulings and Agreements Processing and Support Unit (Processing Unit) if it receives a written request for background ﬁle documents for a determination letter by EO Rulings and Agreements. (
) The Processing Unit locates the determination case ﬁle and provides an elec- tronic copy to the Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch for processing. (
) The Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch will redact all identifying tion and other material required by IRC Section
(c). Disclosure and Litigation support will direct any questions about speciﬁc redactions back to EODQA.

The public may request in writing to receive a redacted copy of the back- ground ﬁle documents for written determinations which have been released for public inspection. The Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch, Legal Pro- cessing Division, Office of the Associate Chief Counsel (Procedure and Administration) is responsible for processing this type of written request.
(06-04-2020) Public Requests for Redacted Background File Documents
The Processing Unit locates the determination case ﬁle and provides an elec- tronic copy to the Disclosure and Litigation Support Branch for processing.
